title.children: When Daniel Hayes disappeared from the AFL, he didn't share his pain — now he is suing his junior coach

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: CNN has cited sources saying the former marine, Daniel Penny, is expected to be charged with manslaughter today. He put a man in a chokehold that killed him on the New York City subway. There have been protests across the city since footage of Jordan Neely being restrained emerged.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former US marine to be charged with manslaughter in choking death on subway

children.content: CNN has cited sources saying the former marine, Daniel Penny, is expected to be charged with manslaughter today.
He put a man in a chokehold that killed him on the New York City subway.
There have been protests across the city since footage of Jordan Neely being restrained emerged.
New York police officers respond to the scene where a fight was reported on a subway train, Monday, May 1.
(AP: Paul martinka)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: WOOHOO! Australia has made it to the final of the Eurovision Song Contest. Australia is represented this year by Perth-based metal-synth band Voyager. The global music spectacle is being held in the British city Liverpool, in place of last year's winner Ukraine. Some of the most competitive countries, including France, Italy, and Israel, have all already secured their spot in this weekend's grand final. It's Australia's final shot at Eurovision for now, as the deal with the European Broadcasting Union is up for renewal this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia reaches the Eurovision finals!

children.content: WOOHOO! Australia has made it to the final of the Eurovision Song Contest.
Australia is represented this year by
Perth-based metal-synth band
Voyager
The global music spectacle is being held in the British city Liverpool, in place of last year's winner Ukraine.
Some of the most competitive countries, including
France
Italy
, and
Israel
, have all already secured their spot in this weekend's grand final.
It's Australia's final shot at Eurovision for now, as the deal with the European Broadcasting Union is up for renewal this year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Twitter boss Elon Musk says he's found a replacement CEO for the social media platform, who will be starting in about six weeks. Musk hasn't named the candidate, but says he'll take on the roles of executive chair and chief technology officer. Tesla shares jumped 2.4 per cent when Musk shared the news. Critics say Musk's tenure as chief executive has sullied the platform's integrity, and its regulation has been grossly undermined by thousands of job cuts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Musk says Twitter has found its next CEO

Elon Musk
says he's found a replacement CEO for the social media platform, who will be starting in
about six weeks

hasn't named the candidate
, but says he'll take on the roles of executive chair and chief technology officer.

when Musk shared the news.

title.children: ASX set to edge lower as Wall St dips on Disney and regional banks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bank of England has kept raising interest rates, with another 0.25 of a percentage point move. " The BoE raised the bank rate 25bp to 4.50%, as was widely expected, the 7-2 vote (two dovish dissenters voting for no change) also as expected. "A more favourable economic outcome of low growth rather than recession and tight labour market conditions were noted. "Guidance remained hawkish – if high inflation persists, they will tighten policy further ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bank of England raises rates by majority vote

children.content: The
Bank of England has kept raising interest rates
, with another 0.25 of a percentage point move.
The BoE raised the bank rate 25bp to 4.50%
, as was widely expected, the 7-2 vote (two dovish dissenters voting for no change) also as expected.
"A more favourable economic outcome of low growth rather than recession and tight labour market conditions were noted.
"Guidance remained hawkish –
if high inflation persists, they will tighten policy further

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Regional banking is the crisis that just won't go away, even though the quickly looming debt ceiling for the US government, with the potential for America to default on its government debts, is gaining more attention at the moment. Overnight, struggling bank PacWest saw its shares dive a further 22.7% after its deposits dropped nearly 10 per cent last week, as savers seek the relative safety of larger institutions. From highs of just under $30 in early February, it's shares ended trade overnight at $4.70. Westpac's Imre Speizer said the US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced some further moves to try and stabilise the banking system overnight. "The US FDIC announced plans to increase fees on all large banks (assets over USD50bn) in order to help covering insured (and potentially uninsured) deposits," he noted. "The proposals also indicated that holders of bank shares would not be protected." The KBW regional bank index ended down 2.4% overall. The other big loser on Wall Street was Walt Disney Corporation, which slumped 8.7% after losing subscribers to its Disney+ streaming service. The following wrap on Disney's quarterly results from Reuters: The decline erased about $16 billion from the company's market value and marked the stock's sharpest single-day fall since Bob Iger's return in November as Disney CEO. Shares of Warner Bros Discovery and Paramount Global fell more than 3%. "Disney+ is losing less money not because it's gaining subscribers but because of its price hikes and better cost management," said Mike Proulx, an analyst at Forrester. "Cutting marketing dollars is at odds with growing subscribers." Operating losses at the streaming unit narrowed by $US400 million in the second quarter from the previous three months, helped by a price hike last December in the US and Canada. The company plans to raise the price of the ad-free Disney+ service again this year and it will also remove certain low-viewership content from its services to cut costs. "Some investors might question this tactic given Disney just lost subscribers," said KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst Brandon Nispel. "However, it seems the goal is to drive more subscribers toward Disney+'s ad-supported tier … which the company believes could improve monetization."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional banks drag Wall St lower, along with Disney

children.content: Regional banking is the crisis that just won't go away, even though the quickly looming debt ceiling for the US government, with the potential for America to default on its government debts, is gaining more attention at the moment.
Overnight, struggling bank
PacWest
saw its shares dive a further 22.7% after its deposits dropped nearly 10 per cent last week, as savers seek the relative safety of larger institutions.
From highs of just under $30 in early February, it's shares ended trade overnight at $4.70.
Westpac's Imre Speizer
said the US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced some further moves to try and stabilise the banking system overnight.
"The US FDIC announced plans to increase fees on all large banks (assets over USD50bn) in order to help covering insured (and potentially uninsured) deposits," he noted.
"The proposals also indicated that holders of bank shares would not be protected."
The KBW regional bank index ended down 2.4% overall.
The other big loser on Wall Street was
Walt Disney Corporation
, which slumped 8.7% after losing subscribers to its Disney+ streaming service.
The following wrap on Disney's quarterly results from
Reuters:
The decline
erased about $16 billion from the company's market value
and marked the stock's sharpest single-day fall since Bob Iger's return in November as Disney CEO.
Shares of
Warner Bros Discovery
and
Paramount Global
fell more than 3%.
"Disney+ is losing less money not because it's gaining subscribers but because of its price hikes and better cost management," said Mike Proulx, an analyst at Forrester.
"Cutting marketing dollars is at odds with growing subscribers."
Operating losses at the streaming unit narrowed by $US400 million in the second quarter from the previous three months, helped by a price hike last December in the US and Canada.
The company plans to raise the price of the ad-free Disney+ service again
this year and it will also remove certain low-viewership content from its services to cut costs.
"Some investors might question this tactic given Disney just lost subscribers," said KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst Brandon Nispel.
"However, it seems the goal is to drive more subscribers toward Disney+'s ad-supported tier … which the company believes could improve monetization."
